body: I like that idea with an own label for each folder! But I don't like that it gets less minimalistic with it. Also it could be a pain to memorise the unique folder id; at the end you will always have to copy & paste it. Currently, you can easily memorise it and set up all your devices with it.

issue.title: Add folder shown in notification "unexpected repository ID sent from device" as new folder

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body: If a user shares a folder with another device the recieving device shows a notification (unexpected repository ID sent from device - see #413) It would be great to add this folder with one click as a new folder and share it with the incoming device, since information about folder ID (and maybe label in the future - #966) and device ID are already there.

body: If you share a folder with a new device, this device will recieve a notification "a folder XYZ is shared with you" (already in Syncthing 0.10.5 - see #413) - in the future when #967 is implemented you could import ID + label with a single click

Oh thats right! I'm sorry, I didn't think of it. Ok, then it makes much more sense to me to implement a label for each folder! Maybe one could even use the node's label that shares the folder as the standard label.

Yeah, but given you do not have the two devices available to connect to each other you'd have to remember the cryptic string to do the setup.
Also this would need a change in the protocol to work as you described as currently there is no place for this, and would break compatibility between devices, plus a tiny change to the warning.

But I guess it's same like having a names for devices, and having to copy Ids, users would just have to deal with it.
From my perspective that would make the experience worse, as it's easy for me to remember `default` or whatever, plus all my labels are always the same, as I only share stuff with my own devices, so this would be noop for me (and probably larger set of users).

I'm not a professional programmer but I think the only limitation would be if special characters a users enters cannot be stored - other than that a label could even be a folder path, text with unicode characters "☕ java projects" etc. which would also be shown in the folder panel header. Under the hood Syncthing would use its great technology together with the unique ID for synchronization

@AudriusButkevicius: I understand - my idea was to get away from the folder ID on user level because there can only be one folder named e.g. "file share" per Syncthing installation, or if you use a naming scheme "fileshare name1-name2" and you have two users with the same name

What I mean `there is no place for this` I mean in the protocol definition, which defines how the structures are serialized into a set of bytes and sent over the wire.

I don't think non-ascii characters are a problem (for go atleast), unless they are a problem for javascript or the raw bytes sent over the wire.

I understand - my idea was to replace folder ID, which is send via the protocol, with a pseudo random ID (maybe last 5 digits of device ID + 5 random digits). Labels are available only locally and stored in config.xml - transferring my label to a new device is nice to have but not required. if the new random ID follows a certain numbering scheme the user only has to tell/copy e.g. last 5 digits to the other user
Yes, but then `WARNING: Unexpected repository ID "A5SFX91293" sent from node` mean's nothing to the user, hence transferring labels would be required.

True - but the idea is that the special folder ID has parts of the remote device ID (e.g. A5SFX) so not extra transfers would be needed. Syncthing could check this agains known devices and output "Folder ID 91293 on device 'Susan's Computer (A5SFX)' has been shared with you". In daily life people usually set up file shares once at the start of a project, so it would be easy to email, IM or SMS the text "folder ID 91293 - project XYZ" to a colleague or team (compared to people emailing info about network shares, which often have cryptic names). Folder labels would also allow to prefix names with numbers or letters to allow simple and individual sorting

Yeah, I think this is something that should be considered. My original use case was for syncing files between a bunch of machines with pretty much the same owner. In that scenario, the current system makes sense. But once you have a bunch of different people it kind of breaks down, when two users want to share their "music" and "documents" folders with you...

Well I'm all for allowing labels but there are problems with automatically generated unique folder IDs. They are great if you have a lot of people sharing similar directory structures (documents, pictures, videos, music...).
But they should very much be optional, or worked around because the current implementation makes it hassle-free for one person to set up a group of devices. This is generally the go-to route for any family or group of friends with one designated "IT guy".

Also copying dozens of folder IDs into a file (in addition to device IDs) if you want to set things up on several devices is a huge pain. Asking the recipient of a share if he wants to accept "XK8SB-KLJASD" from "paul-computer" is similarily horrible UX wise.

I think the easiest way would be to map device IDs to the existing folder IDs and locally store the mapping. In this case duplicate folder IDs aren't a technical problem, but have to be presented in a user friendly way. For example by forcing the use of labels for all newly added folders with a duplicate ID and coloring the folder IDs or their background.
The mapping, coloring scheme and probably labels should also be synced across authorized devices.
This caters well to how people communicate, because they may be unfamiliar with the differences between labels and folder IDs.

Shares with duplicate IDs could then have a little "details" button next to the id which opens a list with the corresponding labels and devices. 

For the folder labeled "Music" on the local machin this could look like this:

Folder ID: shared-music
Also known as:
musica @ santiago_cell
musica @ santiago_computer
Musik @ maximilian_computer
musique partagée @ angelina_laptop

On a technical level mixing globally unique, group unique and locally unique IDs is certainly possible but a nightmare to merge into a user friendly interface.

I would like to respectfully request that this be added to the v1 milestone, if possible,  for all of the above reasons: Sharing folders with similar names (my and my family members "Pictures" folders) is a common usecase...which is poised to get a lot more common once pulse drives ind.ie's heartbeat. Maybe @aral could take this up as an issue to be "adopted" as part of the current funding drive?
#330 should probably be implemented before this.

Duplicate folder labels should be possible and independent from underlying technology. Then the labels could be changed at any time so e.g. teams could simple reuse a setup of folders/devices for their next project. 

@generalmanager 
Labels should _only be available locally_ and not be synced to other devices. This would allow for labels like "project area 51", "important project for painful customer" :smile: If a factory in China shares drawings with a customer in USA it's not really helpful to see a notification for "user XY has shared folder 長頸鹿 with you" - that was the reason for the idea of generated folder IDs.

I agree that automatic IDs are not so easy to remember but they hide "meta data" like project numbers or any other information that can be used for social engineering / hacking, they always work because of a simple ansi charset, etc. - and also if #330 is implemented (and I'm sure @calmh and all other contributers will do a great job) you do not have to type anything. In daily life a user normally tells people that he is sharing something with them, and in most cases it is only a single folder which they can match correctly because of the incomining device. In case of a first time user he needs to get your device ID as well which is then followed by a short explanation on how to connect to the incoming folder you just shared.

> Labels should only be available locally and not be synced to other devices. 

I agree, but I also must say that _some_ transferred information/description might be useful. If I have 5 folders and I add a new computer to share the 5 with, it might be quite confusing what is what.

@uok I'm against breakting things that work well now (setting up groups of shared folders) to improve on other scenarios (shares with duplicate IDs).

How about keeping labels private and asking for a short description of the folder for the recipient.
This should be optional and isn't necessary if you only get one share offer from a new device, which covers the "I want a shared folder with a friend". If you are setting up a bunch of shared resources tough, you'll be happy to have a description of the different shares offered.

If set, this description will be shown instead of an id and should be the default label on the recipients side.

@generalmanager: thanks for your input - to summarize
- Syncthing generates automatic IDs to ensure underlying keys are correct for secure connection
- user can set any label he wants (local unique not needed), which is locally stored (flag private)
- user has option to :ballot_box_with_check: **share label** - this information is then sent to other devices for easy setup (flag public)

Since I only understand parts of how the protocol works maybe @calmh or any other collaborator can inform us if this additional field can be transferred.
